chapters.title: Design of experiment
chapters.text: Before you decide to embark on any new study, it is nowadays good practice to consider all options to keep the data generation part of your study as limited as possible. It is not because we can generate massive amounts of data that we always need to do so. Creating data with public money is bringing with it the responsibility to treat those data well and (if potentially useful) make them available for re-use by others.

questions.title: Is there any pre-existing data?
questions.text: Are there any data sets available in the world that are relevant to your planned research?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: You know that this is very unlikely? This question is not only about data sets that are similar to what you want to determine yourself, but also reference data or data that should be mined from the existing literature. Further, it is very likely that you will refer to related data, e.g. other databases where you usually "quickly look something up", but that could maybe be properly integrated, especially if you need to do such lookups multiple times.

followUps.title: Will you be using any pre-existing data (including other people's data)?
followUps.text: Will you be referring to any earlier measured data, reference data, or data that should be mined from existing literature? Your own data as well as data from others?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Did you research all the data that exists? You may not be aware of all existing data that could be available. Although using and/or integrating existing data sets may pose a challenge, it will normally be cheaper than collecting everything yourself. Even if you decide not to use an existing data set, it is better to do this as a conscious decision.

followUps.title: What reference data will you use?
followUps.text: Much of todays data is used in comparison with reference data. A genome for instance is compared with a reference genome to identify genomic variants. If you use reference data, there are several other issues that you should consider. What are the reference data sets that you will use?

questions.title: Do you know where and how is it available?
questions.text: Do you know where the reference data is available, what the conditions for use are, and how to reference it?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Figure this out quickly!

questions.title: Do you know in what format the reference data is available?
questions.text: Do you know the data format of the reference data? Is this suitable for your work? Does it need to be converted?

answers.label: I need to convert it before using

questions.title: Is the reference data resource versioned?
questions.text: Many reference data sets evolve over time. If the reference data set changes, this may affect your results. If different versions of a reference data set exist, you need to establish your "version policy".

followUps.title: Which version will you use?
followUps.text: If there are different versions available, you have to decide with all project partners together which version you will be using. Probably you will go for the latest release as of the date of the start of your research project. However, if you have other data from older projects that need to be merged, you may need to consider using the same release you used for a previous project.

followUps.title: Will you change version if it updates?
followUps.text: If the reference changes while you are working on your research project, you need to decide whether you will follow these changes. Most likely that will mean that you have to do some analyses again, so you will need to make sure enough resources are available to do so. You can decide to stay with the version that you started with; this can have the disadvantage that you will not benefit from added information or added consistency.

answers.label: Will stay with the old version

followUps.title: How will the old version be available?
followUps.text: Since you want to keep using the old version of the reference data, how will it be available to you?

answers.label: I will need it only at the beginning
I will use a downloaded version
The provider keeps old versions around
New analyses will be done with the new version
All analyses will be redone with the new version

questions.title: How will you make sure the same reference data will be available to reproduce your results?
questions.text: Will the reference data in the version you use be available to others?

answers.label: I will keep a copy and make it available with my results
The provider keeps old versions around

followUps.title: What existing non-reference data sets will you use?
followUps.text: Even if you will be producing your own data, you often will also be relying on existing data sets (e.g. from earlier . You may need to integrate your new data with an existing data set or retrieve additional information from related data bases. Will you be doing such things?

questions.title: Will the owners of this data set work with you on this study

followUps.title: Do you need to request access to the data

questions.title: Will any usage restrictions affect your reuse?
Is extension of any consent for privacy sensitive data needed?
questions.text: If the data that you will re-use is coupled to people, is the informed consent that was originally obtained from those people covering your current research?

questions.title: How will you be accessing the data?

answers.label: Will download or get a copy

questions.title: Do you know in what format the data is available?
questions.text: Do you know the data format of the data? Is this suitable for your work? Does it need to be converted?

answers.label: I need to convert it before using

questions.title: Is the data set fixed, or will it be updated in the future?
questions.text: Is the data set you will reuse a fixed data set (with a persistent identifier), or is it a data set that is being worked on (by others) and may be updated during your project or after?

answers.label: It is a fixed data set, this will not influence reproducibility of my results
It may change
answers.advice: Make sure a copy of the version you use will be available with my results

questions.title: Can you and will you use the complete existing data set?
questions.text: If you use any filtering, how will you make sure that your results will be reproducible by yourself and others at a later time?

answers.label: I will use the complete data set
Any filtering or selection will be well documented
I will make sure the selected subset will be available together with my results

questions.title: Will reference data be created?
questions.text: Will any of the data that you will be creating form a reference data set for future research (by others)?

followUps.title: What will the Intellectual Property be like?
followUps.text: Who will own the rights to the reference data set? Who will be able to use it?

followUps.title: How will you maintain it?
followUps.text: How will maintenance be paid for in the long run? Will you host it yourself or deposit it with a repository? How will you deal with requests for help? And with requests for adding data?

followUps.title: How will the release schedule be?
followUps.text: Will you be updating the reference data at regular intervals?

questions.title: Will you be storing samples?
Will you be collecting experimental data?
Please specify what data sets you will acquire using measurement equipment
Who will do the measurements? And where?
questions.text: Are there easily accessible specialized service providers for data capture?

answers.label: Experts in the project, with our own equipment
Experts in the project, at a specialized infrastructure
External party
answers.advice: consider making them partner in the project

followUps.title: Has formal ownership of the data been established?

answers.label: The party measuring the data owns it
The project partners acquire full ownership

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

answers.label: This still needs to be decided

followUps.title: Has responsibility for long term safe keeping of the raw data been established? Who will deal with data publication?

answers.label: The measuring party will publish it after a fixed embargo period
The measuring party will publish it when the project tells them to
The measuring party will delete the data, the project partners will deal with data publication

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

answers.label: This still needs to be decided

questions.title: Is the equipment completely standard and well described?
questions.text: If the technology is very much under development, you may want to come back later to understand exactly how the measurements have been made. Is the measurement equipment and protocol sufficiently standard that you will be able to explain how it is done or refer to a standard explanation?

answers.label: Less well described or not completely standard
answers.advice: Take pictures of the instruments for documentation, and keep copies of any documentation.

questions.title: Is special care needed to get the raw data ready for processing?
questions.text: Where does the data come from? And who will need it? Sometimes the raw data is measured somewhere else than where the primary processing is taking place. In such cases the ingestion or transport of the primary data may take special planning. You also need to make sure that data is secure and that data integrity is guaranteed.

followUps.title: Is the data format established?
followUps.text: Has the storage and transport format of the primary data been established between the people responsible for the measurement and the people responsible for the processing?

followUps.title: How will the raw data be transported?

answers.label: No transport is needed, analysis is done where it is obtained

followUps.title: Is sufficient writing and reading capacity available for the physical media?
followUps.text: Has time been reserved on any tape/disk reading and writing stations?

answers.label: Yes, has been taken care of

followUps.title: Is sufficient network capacity available?
followUps.text: Can the volume of data be accommodated by the standard network connection? Has a special network connection (e.g. light path) that is needed been reserved?

answers.label: Yes, has been taken care of

followUps.title: Is data integrity guaranteed during this stage?
followUps.text: Do you have any means of identifying whether the raw data has been transferred error free and has not been tampered with?

followUps.title: Is data security guaranteed during this stage?
followUps.text: Are the raw data encrypted or otherwise protected from theft or leaks at either site or during transport? You could e.g. use a light path or a virtual private network if you transport the data over the net.

questions.title: Do you have any non-equipment data capture?
questions.text: Does the data you collect contain non-equipment captured data such as questionnaires, case report forms, electronic patient records?

followUps.title: Will you be collecting questionnaires?
Will you be collecting case report forms?
Will you be collecting data from electronic patient records?
Has access to the electronic patient records been arranged?
Please list all non-equipment data sets you will collect

questions.title: How will the data be captured?

answers.label: Data will first be on paper

followUps.title: Who will do the data entry?

answers.label: One of the members of the project team

followUps.title: What other arrangements?
Did you arrange who will make the data digitally available to you?

questions.title: Will all data be collected by a single person?

answers.label: This data will be collected by one person

followUps.title: Is there a risk of different interpretations? Subjectivity?

answers.label: There are internal controls to deal with interperation differences
We accept the risk of different interpretations

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

questions.title: Is there a data integration tool that can handle and combine all the data types you are dealing with in your project?

followUps.title: Can all data be brought into the same format, e.g. RDF?
What software will you be using to collect all data?

answers.label: We will not use a data warehouse

followUps.title: Why will you develop your own software?

answers.label: Nothing like this has ever been done before
Existing solutions are not suitable
answers.advice: Did you consider collaborating to improve an existing solution?

questions.title: Workflow development
questions.text: It is likely that you will be developing or modifying the workflow for data processing. There are a lot of aspects of this workflow that can play a role in your data management, such as the use of an existing work flow engine, the use of existing software vs development of new components, and whether every run needs human intervention or whether all data processing can be run in bulk once the work flow has been defined.

followUps.title: Will you be exploring options, or run in bulk?
followUps.text: What will be the operational mode for your workflows? Will you be exploring options by changing tools and tweaking parameters? Of will you be running the same exact workflow on a large number of data files?

answers.label: We will be running in bulk

followUps.title: What data will the workflow developers or implementers use?
followUps.text: The people implementing the data analysis work flow for your project probably need test data that they can use to see whether what they build works. How will this be arranged?

answers.label: They can use existing data from another project
They can use data from our project

followUps.title: When will they have access?

answers.label: Data will be available at the start of the project, no waiting needed
They can start with a subset as soon as our first data comes
Workflow development will commence as soon as our data is available

followUps.title: How will data serurity be dealt with?

answers.label: Data security is not an issue
Data will not be on systems owned by workflow developers

followUps.title: What other arrangements?
List existing software components you will use in the analysis workflow
followUps.text: Your workflow may be available in components from different sources. Specify the different parts that you recognize and that you will each acquire in a different way

questions.title: Where are you getting this software from? Please specify a web address if available.
What version of this software will you use?

answers.label: The exact version that we point to
The current version, and we will stick with that
Whatever is the latest version at the time the analysis is run

followUps.title: Will you re-run any analysis when a new version comes out?

answers.label: If there is potentially a better result
answers.advice: Make sure to take that into account when calculating the need for compute resources

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Make sure to take that into account when calculating the need for compute resources

questions.title: How is your experience with this software?

answers.label: We will gather experience by visiting others who have used it

followUps.title: List new software components you will develop for the analysis workflow
followUps.text: Not all components you need may be available already. Please list here what you will be developing yourself. Do not underestimate the time needed to integrate components into a work flow!

questions.title: Please specify the software repository you use for development
questions.text: Preferably use a direct URL other users could use

questions.title: Did you consider existing options?

answers.label: Authors of similar alternatives are not willing to work with us
Alternatives exist, but we prefer to develop our own
This will be one of the prime distinctive outcomes of our project

questions.title: What license will you use for your tool?
questions.text: Make sure the license is compatible with all components you use, and also make sure the license is made explicit in the repository.

answers.label: We are using a different license

followUps.title: What other license?
followUps.text: Preferably give a web pointer to the license.

followUps.title: Is this a recognised reusable open source license?
Did you choose the workflow engine you will be using?

answers.label: Yes, we will be using what we always use
answers.advice: Make sure that you are not missing out on alternatives that would have better properties for the project

answers.label: Yes, we have selected one based on what features we need
Not yet, please guide the choice with more questions on this topic

followUps.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

followUps.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

answers.label: Subject matter experts with a strong computer knowledge
Subject matter experts with no affinity for computer solutions

followUps.title: Does the running of work flows need to be controlled via a GUI?
followUps.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

followUps.text: There is no concrete map of these features to suitable workflow engines at this moment, but filling in these questions can lead you to think about the most important features for the project

followUps.title: Can you make a decision for the workflow engine based on the criteria deemed important?

answers.label: No selection can be made at this point
We will need more than one engine

followUps.title: Do you plan taking special measures to guaranty the integrity of tools in the workflow?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Consider changing this!

followUps.title: Will you only use well-scrutinized open source tools?
Will you have all changes checked by a second developer before deploying them?
How will you handle upgrades to tools?

answers.label: We will trust a new release and deploy
We will offer multiple versions of tools for the end user to choose
We will only deploy selected stable upgrades to tools
We will test all tool changes on a subset of our own data before deployment
We will not change tool versions after the initial selection
answers.advice: Please consider how you will be solving issues/problems you find yourself and that are fixed in a new release

followUps.title: Will you test whether known correct results are obtained over time?

answers.label: Yes, we will regularly make test runs on the same data
Yes, we will automatically make test runs on the same data

followUps.title: Are all tools you use under your complete control?

answers.label: No, we use tools maintained by others

followUps.title: How will you deal with the situation where support for a tool is dropped?

answers.label: We will keep running it unchanged
We will start to do necessary maintenance ourselves
Yes, we only use tools that we can maintain ourselves

questions.title: How will you make sure to know what exactly has been run?

followUps.title: Will you keep results together with all processing scripts or workflows including documentation of the versions of the tools that have been run?
Will you make use of the metadata fields in your output data files to register how the data was obtained?
followUps.text: File formats like VCF (for genetics) and TIFF (for images) have possibilities to document metadata in the file header. It is a good idea to use work flow tools that use these fields to document what was done to obtain the data.

followUps.title: Will you use a central repository for all tools and their versions as used in your project?
followUps.text: Especially if analysis and processing of data in the project is done on multiple different computers by different people, it is a good idea to have your own repository of tools and their blessed versions.

followUps.title: Will you use a central repository for reference data used in your project?
followUps.text: Especially if analysis and processing of data in the project is done on multiple different computers by different people, it is a good idea to have your own repository of reference data versions.

followUps.title: Will you make use of standard workflow engines and automatic work flows for all data analysis in the project?
followUps.text: It is much easier to guarantee consistency and reproducibility if all data processing is done using automated work flows, especially if the workflow engine automatically keeps adequate provenance data.

followUps.title: Are all software tools in the work flow professionally maintained, with version control?
followUps.text: Will you be able to find and reproduce exactly which version was used for any analysis? Not only for the major tools in the workflows, but also for all 'glue' code and small tools you created especially for the project?

questions.title: How will you validate the integrity of the results?

followUps.title: Will you run a subset of your jobs several times across the different compute infrastructures you are using?
followUps.text: There are surprisingly many complications that can cause (slight) inconsistencies between results when workflows are run on different compute infrastructures. A good way to make sure this does not bite you is to run a subset of all jobs on all different infrastructure to check the consistency.

followUps.title: Will you be instrumenting the tools into pipelines and workflows using automated tools?
followUps.text: Surrounding all tools in your data processing and analysis workflows with the 'boilerplate' code necessary on the computer system you are using is tedious and error prone. Especially if you are using the same tools in multiple different work flows and/or on multiple different computer architectures. Automated instrumentation, e.g. by using a workflow management system, can prevent many mistakes.

followUps.title: Will you use independently developed duplicate tools or workflows for critical steps to reduce or eliminate human errors?
followUps.text: Validation of results without a golden standard is very hard. One way of doing it is to develop two solutions for a problem (two independent workflows or two independently developed tools) to check whether the results are identical or comparable.

followUps.title: Will you run part of the data set repeatedly to catch unexpected changes in results?
followUps.text: Running a small subset of the data repeatedly can be useful to catch unexpected problems that would otherwise be very hard to detect.

questions.title: Do you have a contingency plan?
questions.text: What will you do if the compute facility is down?

answers.label: We will wait until the problem is fixed

questions.title: Will data interpretation and modeling require significant compute infrastructure capacity?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Make sure this has been taken into account in the capacity planning under 'Data design and planning'

questions.title: How will you be making sure there is good provenance of the data analysis?
questions.text: Data analysis is normally done manually on a step-by-step basis. It is essential to make sure all steps are properly documented, otherwise results will not be reproducible.

answers.label: We use lab notebooks
answers.advice: Make sure to make the notes available in electronic form along with your data

answers.label: We use an electronic lab notebook

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

questions.title: Will you be doing (automated) knowledge discovery?
Will you be working with the philosophy 'as open as possible' for your data?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: You will need to explain!

questions.title: Can all of your data become completely open immediately?

followUps.title: Are there legal reasons why (some of your) data can not be completely open?
Are there privacy reasons why your data can not be open?
Are there restrictions on where the data need to be stored?

answers.label: Yes, they must stay in the EU
Yes, they must stay in the same country
Yes, they must stay in the same institute

followUps.title: Could pseudonymization be used to make the data more openly available?
followUps.text: Legally, pseudonymous data (which means that someone has the key to reverse the process) is still considered privacy sensitive information. However, the EU is working on special cases where the data can still be opened as long as the key availability is sufficiently limited.

followUps.title: Can you make use of an existing 'trusted third party' for pseudonymization?
followUps.text: Making use of the same pseudonymization for different studies makes it possible to integrate information later. Obviously it also raises the risk of re-identification

followUps.title: Could anonymization be used to make the data more openly available?
followUps.text: Different anonymization techniques exist. Disadvantage of anonymization is that data integration becomes virtually impossible, but it may be the only way to open up your data for other research

followUps.title: Could you use data aggregation to make the data openly available?
followUps.text: Aggregated data, where typically at least 15 individuals are in any data point, are considered sufficiently anonymous. This is an alternative way of making data openly available for future research

followUps.title: Are there IP reasons why your data can not be open?
Is it clear who owns data and documents?
Will someone be given decision power to move documents or data to a new place after the project has finished?
followUps.text: In one case in the past, all documents that had been assembled by a project in a documentation system had to be deleted because not a single person could decide to move them to a new platform when the documentation system was going off-line.

followUps.title: Will you be allowing authenticated access to the data?
Where will the data be stored?

answers.label: In a domain repository (like EBI's EGA) that arranges restricted access
In a national or institutional repository that arranges restricted access
In a dedicated repository
answers.advice: make sure you can guarantee longevity of this repository!

followUps.title: Who will take care of authentication of potential users?

answers.label: We will use username/password authentication, possibly augmented with two-factor security
We will use a single sign-on system such as edugain

followUps.title: What other arrangements?
Who will take care of authorization of potential users?

answers.label: One of the project members will authorize
answers.advice: It is not a good idea to tie this to a person

answers.label: We will set up a data access committee
We will make use of an existing data access committee

followUps.title: Which existing Data Access Committee?
What other arrangements?
Are the criteria for application to access the data openly available?
Has auditing for the re-use been arranged?
Are there business reasons why (some of your) data can not be completely open?

answers.label: Yes, patents still need to be applied for

followUps.title: What other business reasons are there not to open all data immediately?
Are there other reasons why (some of your) data can not be completely open?

answers.label: Yes, papers need to be submitted first

followUps.title: What other reasons are there not to open all data immediately?
Will you use a limited embargo?

answers.label: No, some restricted data will be embargoed indefinitely

followUps.title: What is the maximum embargo period?

answers.label: No, data will be released only as soon as restrictions are falling away
Yes, data that is not legally restrained will be released after a fixed time period, unconditionally

questions.title: Specify a list of data sets you will be publishing
questions.text: Specify a short name for each data set, sufficient for yourself to know what data it is about. It is useful to think about a data set as some collection of data that will be ending up in the same place.

questions.title: What kind of repository will this data be stored in?
questions.text: Domain repositories often have the best functionality to make the data findable and reusable. Many of them are listed in https://fairsharing,org/

followUps.title: What repository?
Will you contact the repository beforehand?
followUps.text: Contacting the repository early may be useful to establish conditions, formats, and metadata requirements for submission. It may also be necessary to establish whether the repository can accommodate your data

answers.label: No, this submission is routine both for us and the repository
Yes, we have contacted the repository
Yes, we will contact the repository

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

answers.label: Our national repository
answers.advice: Disadvantage of a general purpose repository is the lack of data-specific features (e.g. 'play' instead of 'download' for an audio file) and limited findability

answers.label: Our institutional repository
answers.advice: Disadvantage of a general purpose repository is the lack of data-specific features (e.g. 'play' instead of 'download' for an audio file) and limited findability

answers.label: A special-purpose repository for the project

followUps.title: Will you be able to support this repository for a sufficiently long time?
followUps.text: Maintaining a repository is a long term commitment that can most of the time not be funded from project money. Think about who will be doing the system maintenance, hardware maintenance, and who will make necessary code changes to accommodate future (safe) versions of the system

followUps.title: What is the service level you will be offering to users of the data?

answers.label: Download only
answers.advice: That functionality level can surely be found in another place too!

answers.label: A processing service
answers.advice: Make sure to budget sufficient compute resources for the users

followUps.title: Did you arrange for system administration (at least security updates) and hardware maintenance for the server(s)?
What kind of service will your repository offer to users?
followUps.text: The amount of funding needed to maintain a repository is strongly dependent on the services offered

questions.title: Will you be adding a reference to the published data to at least one data catalogue?
questions.text: Data is sometimes difficult to locate, especially if it is not in a domain-specific repository. Data catalogues may increase findability.

questions.title: Will you be making sure that blocks of data deposited in different repositories can be recognized as belonging to the same study?

answers.label: Yes, all data sets will have links to the related data
Yes, all data sets will be linked from a single catalog entry
Yes, we have made other arrangements

followUps.title: What other arrangements?

questions.title: Did you work out the financial aspects of making the data available?

answers.label: This has been taken care of

questions.title: Will your publications be open access?

answers.label: Yes, this is budgeted in the project
Yes, our department/institute will pay for open access publishing

questions.title: Are there any recurring fees to keep data or documents available?
questions.text: Are you using any commercially licensed products to keep data, software or documents available, for which a regular fee must be paid?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Make sure this will be kept running by the department or institute. It is best to also have a backup plan, being able to move data and documents to a different place if a service is discontinued. For this, you may need to arrange permission from all project partners beforehand.

questions.title: Will you be archiving your data after the project in 'cold storage'?
questions.text: Will you be storing (in cold storage) copies of your own data for a longer period after the project has ended? Possibly as a continuation of archival as part of data storage strategy during the project?

followUps.title: Will data formats of data in cold storage be upgraded if they become obsolete?
Will data be migrated regularly to more modern storage media (e.g. newer tapes)?

questions.title: Will you also publish data if the results of your study are negative/inconclusive or unpublishable?
questions.text: Even if you do not obtain the results you had foreseen from your own study, the data can still be valuable for reuse in another context. Also, publishing the data can avoid that someone else collects a similar data set with a similar negative result.

questions.title: Specify a list of software packages you will be publishing
questions.text: Specify a short name for each software package.

questions.title: Will you be adding a proper open-source license?

answers.label: Yes, we have decided on an open source license

followUps.title: What is the license?

answers.label: Yes, we will decide on an open source license

questions.title: Where will the software package be available?
Will this software be listed in a catalogue?
Will there be planning of valorization or translational returns?
How will you be doing the integration of different data sources?

answers.label: This as been taken care of

followUps.title: List the data formats you will be using for data integration
followUps.text: Answer some questions for each

questions.title: How is the data structured?

answers.label: (meta)data fields in a domain specific file

followUps.title: Can all of the data you want to couple be captured in that format?
Will you be doing it that way?
Does the domain specific format come with its own suite of integration tools that you will use??

answers.label: A table or set of tables (consisting of 'data records')

followUps.title: Does each column have a header?
followUps.text: In a table, the data items are arranged in columns. Is there a header for each of these describing what is in there?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: You will need to have a header in order to make the data interoperable and reusable

followUps.title: Are all column headers unambiguous?
followUps.text: A human being quickly 'understands' data items and their relations. For good data reusability, it is necessary that computers can understand your data too.

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Check whether you can find an ontology for each of your data items

followUps.title: Do all columns/headers have a data type?
followUps.text: A label like 'temperature' only makes sense to a computer if it is also clear what the units are and what temperature has been measured. In many cases, it is also important how it was measured.

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Check whether you can find a data type (potentially in a data type registry) for each of your data items

followUps.title: Are the limitations to allowed data values in each column explicit?
followUps.text: If there are reasonable limitations to the values in a column, or even a limited set of allowed values, it is very good for data vvalidation and reusability if these limitations are explicit, and e.g. software used for data entry and editing will not allow anything else.

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Check whether there is a way to explicitly limit data values.

followUps.title: Is it clear what a row in the table represents?
Does each row have an identifier?
Is there a distinguishing way a missing value in the table can be recognized?
followUps.text: Sometimes, and empty field or a zero is indicating a missing value. But is that really unique? Could there be valid empty or zero fields? Has the convention for missing values been made explicit somewhere?

followUps.title: Is the relation between each of the columns and the record identifier clear?
followUps.text: It may appear that in a table with 'patients' as rows, a column labeled 'disease' coupled to an ontology has a clear meaning. But that is not always explicit enough! A 'disease' could e.g. be the disease that the patient is suffering from, but it could also be an earlier diagnose, a suspected diagnose, or the disease a family member recently died of.

followUps.title: Are all the relations between the column headers explicit?
followUps.text: For a good understanding of tabular data, you need to make the relationship between each pair of columns explicit. E.g. if one column is 'disease' and another is 'treatment', you want to make sure that this is the chosen treatment that this person is undergoing for the given disease.

followUps.title: Are you representing the graph in RDF?
followUps.text: RDF is the graph representation used in the 'semantic web'

followUps.title: Are all the URLs resolving to common ontologies?
Describe how?
Will you be using a workflow for data integration, e.g. with tools for database access or conversion?
Will you use a 'linked data' approach?
Are your data sources using linked data?
Will you provide your results as semantically interoperable linked data?

questions.title: Will you be using common or exchangeable units?
Will you be using common ontologies?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Choose the ontologies before you start

questions.title: Will there be potential issues with statistical normalization?
Will you be integrating different data sources to get more samples or more data points?

followUps.title: Have these been collected with sufficiently identical protocols?

questions.title: Will you be integrating different data sources in order to get more information for each sample or data point?

followUps.title: Did you already select the variables on which you will join the data sets?
Will you make sure that you do not inadvertently create a biased subset?
followUps.text: Some parameters you select on may have been collected only for a subset of the subjects or data points. An obvious example is if you match on secondary education type, you will bias to people over 18 years old because younger people do not have this field. In many cases the selection bias may be a lot less obvious and special measures exist to verify that the diversity of the sample is not reduced by the integration step.

followUps.title: Could the coupling of data create a danger of re-identification of anonymized privacy sensitive data?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: Plan either preventative or corrective measures

followUps.title: Did you make a conscious decision to be either accurate or complete?

questions.title: Do you have all tools to couple the necessary data types?

chapters.title: Data design and planning
chapters.text: In the data design and planning phase, we will make sure that we know what data comes when, that we have enough storage space and compute power to deal with it, and that all the responsibilities have been taken care of.

questions.title: What data formats/types will you be using?
questions.text: Have you identified types of data that you will use that are used by others too? Some types of data (e.g. genetic variants in the life sciences) are used by many different projects. For such data, often common standards exist that help to make these data reusable. Are you using such common data formats?

questions.title: Is this a standard data format used by others too?
Does this data format enable sharing and long term archiving?
questions.text: Complicated (binary) file formats tend to change over time, and software may not stay compatible with older versions. Also, some formats hamper long term usability by making use of patents or being hampered by restrictive licensing

followUps.title: Will you convert to a file format more suitable for archiving later?

answers.label: Yes
answers.advice: You may need to reserve time and budget for this

questions.title: Will you be using new types of data?
questions.text: Sometimes the type of data you collect can not be stored in a commonly used data format. In such cases you may need to make your own, keeping interoperability as high as possible.

answers.label: No, all of my data will fit in common formats
Yes, I will need to use custom formats for some of my data

followUps.title: Will you need to add fields in your data format to a data type registry?
followUps.text: Even if the data format you are using is unique to your project, the discrete data items should be reused or reusable as much as possible. Data type registries can help with that.

answers.label: No, all of my data types are described in a data type registry already
Yes, I will add new types to an existing data type registry
Yes, I will create my own data type registry

followUps.title: Which data type registries will you use?
Do you need to create vocabularies or ontologies for any of your data items?
followUps.text: For good interoperability the use of controlled vocabularies for each discrete data item is advisable. If such vocabularies exist, it is best to reuse those.

answers.label: No, suitable public controlled vocabularies or ontologies exist for all of my data types
Yes, I will make and publish a vocabulary or ontology for some of my data

followUps.title: How will you design your new data format?

answers.label: There is a closely related more generic and open format that I can specialize
I will use a Linked Data format
I will use a completely custom data format

followUps.title: Will you describe your new data format for others?

answers.label: Yes, I will register my standards at a data standards registry

questions.title: How will you be storing metadata?
questions.text: For the re-usability of your data by yourself or others at a later stage, a lot of information about the data, how it was collected and how it can be used should be stored with the data. Such data about the data is called metadata, and this set of questions are about this metadata

followUps.title: Do suitable 'Minimal Metadata About ...' (MIA...) standards exist for your experiments?

answers.label: No
answers.advice: Did you really check a service like fairsharing.org to verify this?

followUps.title: Do you have a good idea of what metadata is needed to make it possible for others to read and interpret your data in the future?
Do you know how and when you will be collecting the necessary metadata?
followUps.text: Often it is easiest to make sure you collect the metadata as early as possible.

followUps.title: Will you consider re-usability of your data beyond your original purpose?
followUps.text: Adding more than the strict minimum metadata about your experiment will possibly allow more wide re-use of your data, with associated higher data citation rates. Please note that it is not easy for yourself to see all other ways in which others could be reusing your data.

answers.label: No, I will just document the bare minimum
Yes, I will document more metadata than needed for reproducibility

followUps.title: How will you balance the extra efforts with the potential for added reusability?

answers.label: I will see what I can do
I will use preselected additional standard modules of metadata
I will collect all metadata I can gather and document the data set beyond minimal standards

followUps.title: Do you need to exchange your data with others?
Did you consider how to monitor data integrity?
followUps.text: Working with large amounts of heterogenous data in a larger research group has implications for the data integrity. How do you make sure every step of the workflow is done with the right version of the data? How do you handle the situation when a mistake is uncovered? Will you be able to redo the strict minimum data handling?

followUps.title: Will you be keeping a master list with checksums of certified/correct/canonical/verified data?
followUps.text: Data corruption or mistakes can happen with large amounts of files or large files. Keeping a master list with data checksums can be helpful to prevent expensive mistakes. It can also be helpful to keep the sample list under version control forcing that all changes are well documented.

followUps.title: Will you define a way to detect file or sample swaps, e.g. by measuring something independently?
Do all datasets you work with have a license?
followUps.text: It is not always clear to everyone in the project (ad outside) what can and can not be done with a data set. It is helpful to associate each data set with a license as early as possible in the project. A data license should ideally be as free as possible: any restriction like 'only for non-commercial use' or 'attribution required' may reduce the reusability and thereby the number of citations. If possible, use a computer-readable and computer actionable license.

followUps.title: Will you store the licenses with the data at all time?
followUps.text: It is very likely that data will be moved and copied. At some point people may lose track of the origins. It can be helpful to have the licenses (of coarse as open as possible) stored in close association with the data.

followUps.title: How will you keep provenance?
followUps.text: To make your experiments reproducible, all steps in the data processing must be documented in detail. The software you used, including version number, all options and parameters. This information together for every step of the analysis is part of the so-called data provenance. There are more questions regarding this in the chapter on data processing and curation.

answers.label: All steps will be documented in an (electronic) lab notebook
Our work flow system documents the provenance automatically and completely

followUps.title: How will you do file naming and file organization?
followUps.text: Putting some thoughts into file naming can save a lot of trouble later.

followUps.title: Did you make a SOP (Standard Operating Procedure) for file naming?
followUps.text: It can help if everyone in the project uses the same naming scheme.

followUps.title: Will you be keeping the relationships between data clear in the file names?
followUps.text: Advice: Use the same identifiers for sample IDs etc throughout the entire project.

followUps.title: Will all the metadata in the file names also be available in the proper metadata?
followUps.text: The file names are very useful as metadata for people involved in the project, but to computers they are just identifiers. To prevent accidents with e.g. renamed files metadata information should always also be available elsewhere and not only through the file name.

answers.label: No, the file names in the project are an essential part of the metadata
Yes, all metadata is also explicitly available elsewhere

questions.title: Will you be archiving data (using so-called 'cold storage') for long term preservation?
questions.text: Much of the raw data you have will need to be archived for your own later use somewhere. This is often done off-line on tape, not on the disks of the compute facility. Please note that this does not refer to the data publication; questions related to data publication will follow later.

followUps.title: Can the original data be regenerated?
When is the raw data archived?

answers.label: As soon as it comes in, in chunks
As soon as it has all arrived, in one session
All at once with the results at the end of the project

followUps.title: Is the archived data changing over time, needing re-archival?
Do you need frequent backups?
followUps.text: The general term 'backup' is used for protection against two different kinds of problems: equipment failure and human error. Protections against these two may need different solutions. Both are considered backup for this and subsequent questions.

followUps.title: Will you be relying on these backups to recover from human error (accidental changes or deletions)?
Will the archive be stored on disk or on tape?
Will the archive be stored in a remote location, protecting the data against disasters?
Will the archive need to be protected against loss or theft?
Will the archive be encrypted?
Is it clear who has access to the key? Also in case of a required data restore?
Is it clear who has physical access to the archives?
Will your project require the archives to be available on-line?
Will data integrity be guaranteed?
followUps.text: If the 'master copy' of the data is available on line, it should probably be protected against being tampered with.

followUps.title: Is there an interface and a defined process for people to request access to the data?
Has it been established who has access to the archive, and how fast?
Has it been established who can ask for a restore during the project?
If the data is voluminous, will the project be able to cope with the time needed for a restore?
has authority over the data been arranged for when the project is finished (potentially long ago)? Is there a data access committee?
Has it been established how long the archived data need to be kept? For each of the different parts of the archive (raw data / results)?
Will the data still be understandable after a long time?
followUps.text: See also all questions about keeping metadata and data formats. Make sure the metadata is kept close to the data in the archive, and that community supported data formats are used for all long term archiving.

questions.title: Will you need a shared working space to work with your data?

followUps.title: Are data all project members store adequately backed up and traceable?

answers.label: Yes, protected against both equipment failure and human error

followUps.title: How will you work with your data?
What kind of data will you have in your work space?
followUps.text: When making the work space, it helps to know whether you expect to work with very many small files, a few very large files, whether you will use a (SQL) database to store most of the data. Maybe your data is suitable for a system like Hadoop? Such information can be collected here.

followUps.title: Do you need the work space to be close to the compute capacity?
followUps.text: If you have large volumes of data that are intensely and repeatedly used by the computing work flow, it may be needed to keep the storage in the same place as where the computing takes place.

followUps.title: Will you be working with your data in another form than the way it will be archived?
followUps.text: Archival and working with data have different requirements. You want archived information to be in a form that others could read and in a format that is also understandable in a number of years. When working with the data, you need to be able to address it efficiently. If the two differ, you need to plan for conversions.

answers.label: No, data format will be archived in the same way we work with it
Yes, archival will require a conversion step

followUps.title: How does the storage need change over time?
followUps.text: To perform capacity planning, it is important to know what the need for storage capacity at the beginning and the end of the project will be.

answers.label: Storage needs will be the same during the whole project
Storage needs are large at the beginning and will be reduced later
Storage needs are small at the beginning and will grow later
Storage needs are largest in the middle of the project

followUps.title: When will your raw data become available?

answers.label: Raw data will come in right at the start
Raw data will come in during the project

followUps.title: How much of the raw data do you need to keep in the work space?
followUps.text: Sometimes the raw data is relatively large, and it pays of to clean it quickly.

answers.label: Raw data will need to stay in the work space
Raw data can be cleaned out or archived quickly

followUps.title: Do your raw data need to be archived?

answers.label: No, it is also stored elsewhere can be recovered easily
No, it can be remeasured easily and more cheaply than archiving
Raw data do not form a major part of the storage needs
Raw data will only be loaded in the work space on demand from the primary archives

followUps.title: Did you plan how much intermediate data you will get during analysis and how long each step needs to be kept?

answers.label: The volume of intermediate data will not be significant
A large volume of intermediate data will be in the work space

followUps.title: Is it possible to store intermediate temporary data on a separate (scratch) file system that is not backed up?
followUps.text: If the intermediate results are in your main work space, a restore in case of a problem could take much more time. It may be faster to recover it by re-running computations

answers.label: We will use the main work space for temporary data
We can offload intermediate results to a scratch file system that is not backed up

followUps.title: Are you sure you will not need a backup of the data stored on the scratch file systems (any scratch you use)?
Will you have different versions of intermediate data that need to be kept?
followUps.text: Consider storing only the workflow parameters if the data itself could be reproduced quickly

followUps.title: Will you need to temporarily archive data sets (e.g. to tape)?
How will your first data come in?

answers.label: No special planning is needed for the initial data
Initial data will need to be made available through a local network copy
We will need a high-speed network connection to copy the initial data
Initial data will arrive on separate media and will need to be copied to the work space

followUps.title: How will project partners access the work space?
Who will arrange access control?

answers.label: Project management will need to be able to give people access
The work space should be connected to a single-sign-on system

followUps.title: Will the work space storage need to be remote mounted?

answers.label: Yes, for actual computations, requiring high performance

followUps.title: Will data be copied out and in to the workspace storage by remote users?

answers.label: No, this should not be allowed
Yes, for actual computations, requiring high performance

followUps.title: Are data integrity and reliability requirements also met by the other storage spaces used in the project?
How available/reliable should must the work space be?
followUps.text: There are a number of questions that can help you to decide whether your work space will be reliable enough for your project. Do you want to skip those questions now, or go through them?

followUps.title: What is the acceptable risk for a total loss?

answers.label: All essential data is also stored elsewhere

followUps.title: Is there software in the work space? Can it also be restored quickly?

answers.label: Software in the work space is only a copy
Special care will be taken for the software and configurations

followUps.title: Can you handle it when the work space is off line for a while?

answers.label: We could handle a few days of offline time per year
We can only miss the work space for a few hours during work hours
Problems during the evenings and weekends can not wait for work hours to be repaired

followUps.title: How long can you wait for a restore if the storage fails?

answers.label: We can wait for repair and a restore
A spare copy needs to be deployed quickly
No waiting is possible, a hot copy must be ready to take over

followUps.title: How long can you wait for a restore if you accidentally damage a file?

answers.label: Any user needs to be able to restore an old copy instantaneously

followUps.title: Do you need to make copies of project data that is not in the work space?
followUps.text: Are there any data files e.g. on laptops of project members? Also: supercomputing centers and other high performance computer centers often write in their terms of use that you need to take care of your own backups

answers.label: All data elsewhere is adequately backed up
We make (automated) backups of all data stored outside of the working area

questions.title: Is the risk of information loss, leaks and vandalism acceptably low?
questions.text: There are many factors that can contribute to the risk of information loss or information leaks. They are often part of the behavior of the people that are involved in the project, but can also be steered by properly planned infrastructure.

followUps.title: Do project members store data or software on computers in the lab or external hard drives connected to those computers?
followUps.text: When assessing the risk, take into account who has access to the lab, who has (physical) access to the computer hardware itself. Also consider whether data on those systems is properly backed up

followUps.title: Do project members carry data with them?
followUps.text: Does anyone carry project data on laptops, USB sticks or other external media?

followUps.title: Are all data carriers encrypted? Are accounts on the laptop password protected?
Do project members store project data in cloud accounts?
followUps.text: Think about services like Dropbox, but also about Google Drive, Apple iCloud accounts, or Microsoft's Office365

followUps.title: Do project members send project data or reports per e-mail or other messaging services?
Do all data centers where project data is stored carry sufficient certifications?
Are all project web services addressed via secure http (https://)?
Have project members been instructed about the risks (generic and specific to the project)?
followUps.text: Project members may need to know about passwords (not sharing accounts, using different passwords for each service, and two factor authentication), about security for data they carry (encryption, backups), data stored in their own labs and in personal cloud accounts, and about the use of open WiFi and https

followUps.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information is lost?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

followUps.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information leaks?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

followUps.title: Did you consider the possible impact to the project or organization if information is vandalized?

answers.label: Yes; the risk is acceptably low
Yes; we will need to work on this.

questions.title: Do you need to do compute capacity planning?
questions.text: If you require substantial amounts of compute power, amounts that are not trivially absorbed in what you usually have abailable, some planning is necessary. Do you think you need to do compute capacity planning?

followUps.title: Do you know how much CPU power, memory and I/O band width a typical analysis will take?
followUps.text: Did you run pilot jobs? Do you know this information from comparable projects? Did you test whether the work scales up as you expected if you run more than one job?

followUps.title: What type of compute architecture is most suitable for your work? Will you have that available?

answers.label: We will use a compute cluster
We will use a mix of computing architectures for different parts of the work

followUps.title: Is there sufficient experience with the chosen computer in the project, and sufficient time to support the project partners?

answers.label: Our people will be able to call for help
We have sufficient knowledge in the project

followUps.title: Have you established with the provider when will you need the compute capacity?
followUps.text: Do you need the compute capacity also for development? Can you start developing locally and start with a deployment test later?

followUps.title: Is all required compute capacity available close to the project working storage area?
Did you plan the required network capacity between storage and compute services?

answers.label: There are no special networking requirements
Copying or network delays are considered to be acceptable
We will be able to use a dedicated network connection

followUps.title: Can all data be legally transported and processed at the computing site?
followUps.text: Are the risks of data leaks covered?

followUps.title: Will different groups work on different parts of the workflow? Will parts of the computing be done on 'local' infrastructure to the group?

answers.label: All steps of the workflow will be performed at central computing locations
Some steps may be performed at local computing locations

followUps.title: Is there sufficient network capacity to the other computing locations?
